title: Trade of nuclear commodities
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.0     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.3     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.0.1     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(here)


here() starts at /workspaces/report-nuclearpower


First, letâ€™s download the data from the European Commission:


Code
base_url <-
  "https://cidportal.jrc.ec.europa.eu/ftp/jrc-opendata/NUCLEAR-TRADE-ATLAS/"
dest_path <- here("data", "raw")

files <- tibble(
  file = "NUCLEAR_TRADE_ATLAS_DATA_2023.zip",
  url = paste0(base_url, file),
  dest = file.path(dest_path, file))

# download and unzip the files if the csvs don't exist
if (!all(file.exists(files$dest))) {
  dir.create(dest_path, showWarnings = FALSE)
  files |>
    mutate(
      dl = walk2(url, dest, download.file),
      unzip = walk(dest, unzip, exdir = dest_path))
}


Letâ€™s open the two files up:


Code
tibble(
  path = list.files(dest_path, pattern = glob2rx("*.csv"), full.names = TRUE)) |>
  mutate(data = map(path, read_csv)) |>
  unnest(data) |>
  janitor::clean_names() ->
all_data


Rows: 96210 Columns: 13
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (10): COMMODITY DESCRIPTION, FLOW, NUCLEAR COMMODITY DESCRIPTION, PARTNE...
dbl  (3): COMMODITY CODE, QUANTITY KG, VALUE USD

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Nigel Marks from Curtin University has helped us classify the commodities described in the commodity_code, commodity_description and nuclear_commodity_description columns.


Code
here("data", "nuclear-commodity-categories.csv") |>
  read_csv() |>
  print() |>
  select(-nuclear_commodity_description) ->
categories


Rows: 22 Columns: 3
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): nuclear_commodity_description, category
dbl (1): commodity_code

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


# A tibble: 22 Ã— 3
   commodity_code nuclear_commodity_description     category                    
            <dbl> <chr>                             <chr>                       
 1          2844. Radioactive elements and isotopes Unclear - perhaps ignore    
 2          8401. Fuel elements, non-irradiated     Fuel fabrication            
 3          8102. Tungsten articles                 Ignore - probably related tâ€¦
 4          8112. Beryllium                         Probably ignore             
 5          8112. Beryllium                         Probably ignore             
 6          8112. Beryllium                         Probably ignore             
 7          2844. Depleted uranium; thorium         Enrichment                  
 8          2844. Enriched uranium; plutonium       Enrichment                  
 9          2845. Heavy water                       Power Plant                 
10          2844. Irradiated fuel elements          Spent Fuel / HLW            
# â„¹ 12 more rows


Weâ€™ll have a look at the commodities marked â€œIgnoreâ€ as well to see how they big they are, but weâ€™re approaching on the assumption that theyâ€™re mostly not related to fission.
Letâ€™s merge those categories in:


Code
all_data |>
  left_join(categories, join_by(commodity_code), multiple = "all",
    unmatched = "error") |>
  glimpse() ->
joined_data


Rows: 96,210
Columns: 15
$ path                          <chr> "/workspaces/report-nuclearpower/data/raâ€¦
$ commodity_code                <dbl> 2844.40, 8401.30, 8101.99, 8101.99, 2844â€¦
$ commodity_description         <chr> "Radioactive elements, isotopes and compâ€¦
$ flow                          <chr> "Export", "Export", "Export", "Export", â€¦
$ nuclear_commodity_description <chr> "Radioactive elements and isotopes", "Fuâ€¦
$ partner                       <chr> "Libya", "Sudan", "Niger", "Ethiopia", "â€¦
$ partner_iso2                  <chr> "LY", "SD", "NE", "ET", "DZ", "EG", "MA"â€¦
$ partner_iso3                  <chr> "LBY", "SDN", "NER", "ETH", "DZA", "EGY"â€¦
$ period                        <chr> "12/31/2017", "12/31/2017", "12/31/2017"â€¦
$ reporter                      <chr> "Tunisia", "Egypt", "Algeria", "Egypt", â€¦
$ reporter_iso2                 <chr> "TN", "EG", "DZ", "EG", "ZA", "ZA", "ZA"â€¦
$ reporter_iso3                 <chr> "TUN", "EGY", "DZA", "EGY", "ZAF", "ZAF"â€¦
$ quantity_kg                   <dbl> 231, 0, 90, 1, 10, 272, 108, 100, 1, 968â€¦
$ value_usd                     <dbl> 69653, 30, 164, 32, 53930, 20071, 19889,â€¦
$ category                      <chr> "Unclear - perhaps ignore", "Fuel fabricâ€¦


Weâ€™ll also rearrange the countries slightly. In Comtrade, the database from which this Atlas is derived:

exports are trades from the reporter to the partner (ie. the reporter in the source and the partner is the recipient), while
imports go from the partner to the reporter (ie. the reporter is the recipient and the partner is the source).

Letâ€™s derive the source and recipient:


Code
joined_data |>
  mutate(
    source = if_else(flow == "Export", reporter, partner),
    source_iso3 = if_else(flow == "Export", reporter_iso3, partner_iso3),
    recipient = if_else(flow == "Export", partner, reporter),
    recipient_iso3 = if_else(flow == "Export", partner_iso3, reporter_iso3)) ->
mapped_data


Now weâ€™ll sum up commodities within each category (still split by year and by trading partners):


Code
mapped_data |>
  # lump all the "ignore" categories together
  mutate(category = if_else(
    str_detect(category, fixed("ignore", ignore_case = TRUE)),
    "Ignore",
    category)) |>
  # all period dates are dec 31 for that year
  mutate(year = year(mdy(period))) |>
  # sum up all commodities within category
  group_by(source, source_iso3, recipient, recipient_iso3, year, category, flow) |>
  summarise(
    value_usd = sum(value_usd, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  ungroup() |>
  select(-flow) |>
  distinct(.keep_all = TRUE) |>
  write_csv(here("data", "nuclear-commodity-data.csv")) ->
category_data


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'source', 'source_iso3', 'recipient',
'recipient_iso3', 'year', 'category'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.


Now letâ€™s sum it up across years, too:


Code
category_data |>
  group_by(source, source_iso3, recipient, recipient_iso3, category) |>
  summarise(sum_value_usd = sum(value_usd, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  ungroup() |>
  write_csv(here("data", "nuclear-commodity-data-allyears2023.csv")) ->
allyears_data


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'source', 'source_iso3', 'recipient',
'recipient_iso3'. You can override using the `.groups` argument.

title: Use of nuclear energy
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4     âœ” readr     2.1.5
âœ” forcats   1.0.0     âœ” stringr   1.5.0
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.0     âœ” tibble    3.2.1
âœ” lubridate 1.9.3     âœ” tidyr     1.3.1
âœ” purrr     1.0.1     
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
# library(glue)
# library(sf)
# library(rgeoboundaries)
library(countrycode)
# library(lwgeom)
# library(jsonlite)
library(here)


here() starts at /workspaces/report-nuclearpower


The data here is from the International Renewable Energy Agency.
The tables (which can be updated by downloading them from IRENASTAT and placing them in data as irena-src-[measure][grid_status].csv) are:

Installed electricity capacity by country/area (MW) by Country/area, Technology, Grid connection and Year
Electricity generation (GWh) by Country/area, Technology, Grid connection and Year



Code
tibble(
  path = list.files(here("data"), full.names = TRUE,
    pattern = glob2rx("irena-src-*.csv")),
  filename = basename(path)) |>
  mutate(
    data = map(path, read_csv,
      skip = 3,
      col_names = c("country", "tech", "grid", "year", "value"),
      col_types = "cccid",
      na = c("", "NA", ".."))) |>
  separate(filename,
    into = c("irena", "src", "measure", "grid", "ext"), sep = "[-.]") |>
  select(measure, data) |>
  unnest(data) ->
irena_bound


Weâ€™re going to classify these sources as either Nuclear, renewable or non-renewable.


Code
irena_bound |>
  mutate(
    energy_type = case_match(tech,
      c(
        "Solar photovoltaic",   "Solar thermal energy",
        "Onshore wind energy",  "Offshore wind energy",
        "Renewable hydropower", "Mixed Hydro Plants",
        "Pumped storage",       "Marine energy",
        "Solid biofuels",       "Renewable municipal waste",
        "Liquid biofuels",      "Biogas",
        "Geothermal energy") ~ "renewable",
      "Nuclear" ~ "nuclear",
      .default = "nonrenewable")) |>
  # calculate the amount and proportion in each tech bucket
  group_by(measure, country, year, energy_type) |>
  summarise(amount = sum(value, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  mutate(prop = amount / sum(amount, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  ungroup() |>
  # pivot out the amounts and proportions by tech type
  mutate(measure = recode(measure,
    "generation" = "totalgen.gwh", "capacity" = "totalcap.mw")) |>
  pivot_wider(
    id_cols = c(country, year),
    names_from = c(measure, energy_type), names_sep = "_",
    values_from = c(amount, prop)) ->
irena_wide


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'measure', 'country', 'year'. You can
override using the `.groups` argument.


Finally, we also need ISO codes and centroids for the new data. Iâ€™m going to use nuclear-commodity-centroids, which has country names and ISO3 codes.


Code
here("data", "nuclear-commodity-centroids.csv") |>
  read_csv() ->
centroids


Rows: 245 Columns: 4
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): iso3, name
dbl (2): lat, lon

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
irena_wide |>
  left_join(centroids, join_by(country == name), multiple = "all",
    unmatched = "drop") ->
irena_centroids


Warning in left_join(irena_wide, centroids, join_by(country == name), multiple = "all", : Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
â„¹ Row 3750 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
â„¹ Row 1 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
â„¹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
  "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.


Code
# check the unmatched countries
irena_wide |>
  anti_join(centroids, join_by(country == name)) ->
unmatched

unmatched |> pull(country) |> unique()

 [2] "Antigua and Barbuda"                                       
 [3] "Bahamas (the)"

 [9] "Cayman Islands"                                            
[10] "Central African Republic (the)"                            
[11] "China, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region"            
[12] "Chinese Taipei"                                            
[13] "Comoros (the)"                                             
[14] "Congo (the)"                                               
[15] "Cook Islands (the)"                                        
[16] "Curaï¿½ao"                                                   
[17] "Cï¿½te d'Ivoire"                                             
[18] "Democratic People's Republic of Korea (the)"               
[19] "Democratic Republic of the Congo (the)"                    
[20] "Dominican Republic (the)"                                  
[21] "Eswatini"                                                  
[22] "Falkland Islands (Malvinas)"                               
[23] "Faroe Islands"                                             
[24] "French Guiana"                                             
[25] "Gambia (the)"                                              
[26] "Guadeloupe"                                                
[27] "Iran (Islamic Republic of)"                                
[28] "Lao People's Democratic Republic (the)"                    
[29] "Marshall Islands (the)"

Okay, we have a lot of unmatched countries â€” 66! Matching using country name often goes askew ğŸ˜… Letâ€™s see if the {countrycode} package can do any better:


Code
irena_wide |>
  mutate(iso3_countrycode = countrycode(country, "country.name", "iso3c")) |>
  filter(is.na(iso3_countrycode)) |>
  select(country, iso3_countrycode) |>
  distinct()

Countrycode warns about a few match failures (just a few now!), but these mostly appear to be the result of a text encoding error (ie. the source files arenâ€™t UTF-8).
Iâ€™m having some trouble getting purrr::map to work with different encodings, so I might just patch these manually and move on. Letâ€™s also get rid of (the) and (... of):


Code
irena_wide |>
  mutate(
    country = case_match(country,
      "Curaï¿½ao" ~ "Curacao" ,
      "Saint Barthï¿½lemy" ~ "Saint BarthÃ©lemy",
      "Tï¿½rkiye" ~ "Turkey",
      .default = country),
    iso3_countrycode = countrycode(country, "country.name", "iso3c")) |>
  left_join(centroids, join_by(iso3_countrycode == iso3), multiple = "all",
    unmatched = "drop") |>
  select(-name) |>
  select(iso3_countrycode, country, lat, lon, year, everything()) ->
irena_centroids

Still a few non-matches (15), but most of them are quite small and difficult to match. Letâ€™s write it out!


Code
irena_centroids |>
  write_csv(here("data", "irena-proportions.csv"))

# and also the latest data only
latest_year <- max(irena_centroids$year, na.rm = TRUE)
irena_centroids |>
  filter(year == max(year, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  write_csv(here("data", paste0("irena-proportions-", latest_year, ".csv")))
